Description: Hollow terracotta figure of Bes standing, naked and armed, with sword held high and a circular shield on his left arm. He wears a feathered crown and has an amulet hanging round his neck. Back plain; pierced suspension-lug behind crown. The legs lost at the ankles. Two-piece mould. Brown Nile silt, with mica in very small particles. Traces of a dressing on the front, coloured pink.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: W.L. Hildburgh. Ptolemaic, probably third to second century BC. Comparanda: Near: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1881.57, acquired by the vendor at Bubastis, and 1896-1908.E4700-01, thought to be from Naukratis; Breccia 1934: no. 189; Ewigleben and von Grumbkow 1991: no. 51; Ghalioungui and Wagner 1974: pl. 61e; Hilton Price 1897: 394, no. 3269 (but with Gaulish shield), from Bubastis; Roeder 1937: pl. 13c, from Hermopolis Magna; Török 1995: no. 16, dated late second and first century BC.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3095)
Acquisition name: Donated by: Dr W L Hildburgh
